text: All right.  [Tomorrow] we’re going to play a fraction [track] game.  Look at the fraction track game board that you have in front of you.  Tell me some things that you notice about it.  Yes?
speaker: teacher

text: It starts at 0 and goes to 1.  What starts at 0?
speaker: teacher

text: The beginning of each track starts at 0 and goes to 1.  Yes.
speaker: teacher

text: Hmm, in order.  What do you mean?
speaker: teacher

text: So each track is going in order from 0 to 1, and say that again, what you just said?
speaker: teacher

text: Some are done for you and some are missing.  All right. Today [inaudible] marking and labeling your graphs [inaudible] so we can play the game tomorrow.  The materials you can use are your pencil, and I gave you each a ruler.  If you don’t have a ruler, raise your hand.  Perfect.  All right. I also have in here –
speaker: teacher

text: We’re going to shrink it and try to make it –.  I can adjust it.
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  Let’s look at the halves.  Using your ruler, what do you notice about the halves?  Look at your first draft, the halves.  Using your ruler, tell me something that you notice.
speaker: teacher

text: Student C said that she noticed from 0 to one-half was 4 inches.  What else?  Yes?
speaker: teacher

text: Or 10 centimeters from 0 to the half.  So I’m going to put my ruler [inaudible] half is 10 centimeters.  You can’t really see that well with mine, but you have your own in front of you.  Then what about one-half to 1?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  Student G chose to use the inch side, and she says from 0 to one-half is 4 inches, and from one-half to 4 is also 4 inches.  So, does that prove that the one-half is exactly in the middle?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  What you’re going to do today is you’re going to fill in the rest of it.  Watch me.  I’m going to show you something that’s going to be a tool that you could use to fill in the rest of it.  I want you to take your ruler and I want you to put in, vertically from the one-half all the way down so that it looks like this, and actually connecting on a dot that’s at the bottom of the fraction track.  Look at what I did.  No.  See, the edge of the ruler.  Edge of the ruler. Not the line in the middle of the ruler.  The edge of the ruler.
speaker: teacher

text: There you go.  It’s lined up.  Good.  And that’s it.
speaker: teacher

text: What can you tell me is happening labeling this?  Yes.
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  So what he’s saying is the dot at the bottom of the fraction track is also equivalent to one-half.  Where does the fraction track start on this?
speaker: teacher

text: 0 what?  Zero tenths.  So, can somebody tell me what we’re going to label this dot right here?
speaker: teacher

text: Do you see what I did here, Student M?  So this dot at the bottom here – see where I’m pointing?  What are we going to label that?  You were saying a half, but we’re dealing with zero tenths at the beginning.  So can you think of how many tenths is going to be equal to that?
speaker: teacher

text: Five-tenths.  So now label yours five-tenths.
speaker: teacher

text: I heard Student J say because it’s equivalent.  Very good.  So five tenths.
speaker: teacher

text: So one-half is equivalent to how many tenths?
speaker: teacher

text: One-half is equivalent to how many tenths?  How many?  Five tenths.  So what are you going to label this?  Five-tenths. What are you going to label your dot here?
speaker: teacher

text: Boys and girls, I have it up here, so that you can look to check yours.
speaker: teacher

text: Oh, can you say it louder?
speaker: teacher

text: So Student A just said that if he goes down to the fourths, the eighths – which one did you say?
speaker: teacher

text: On the eighths – he’s saying that he knows four-eighths is also equal to a half.  So we’re going to put a dot right in line there, on the eighths track, right here, and Student A wants to label it four-eighths.  Does everybody agree?
speaker: teacher

text: On two-fifths, if you [inaudible] that line, [inaudible] four- tenths.
speaker: student

text: Okay, Student D, can you stay with the halves for right now?  I like where you were going with that.  Student D, can you give me another fraction that would be equivalent to one- half that we could put on our track?  So Student D wants to go again to the fourths.  So if I am the fourths track, put a dot halfway, and we’re going to label it what?
speaker: teacher

text: Two-fourths.  Good job.  So these are all lined up.  Okay. Student G says that three-sixths is also equivalent to what?
speaker: teacher

text: One-half.  So we’re going to find halfway on the sixths track, put a dot, and we’re going to label it what?
speaker: teacher

text: Three-sixths.  Great job.  Okay.  Now, you can also take your ruler – like you did with the halves – and you could measure halfway.  So if I measure halfway from zero-fourths to two-fourths, what should I have?  How many inches?  How many inches?
speaker: teacher

text: Student B is going to tell us.
speaker: teacher

text: How many inches?  Put your ruler on the fourths track, the one that we just did.
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  How many inches would it be from zero-fourths to two- fourths?  Four inches.  How many inches would it be, Student A, from two-fourths over to 1?
speaker: teacher

text: Four inches.  So it’s safe to say that when we did this, all of our tracks are halfway.  All right.  What you’re going to do – I’m going to let you go off and I’m going to let you label the rest of the tracks yourself.  If you are having difficulty, these are the tracks that you need to have.  So we just completed the halves, are done.  So the thirds. Find the thirds track.  You have labeled one-thirds done for you.  One-third, two-thirds, and three-thirds are done for you.  The fourths, the fifths, sixths, eighths, and tens.  These are the tracks that you are labeling on your tracks.  Some of them are done for you.  Okay.  We’re going to be looking for – what are we going to be looking for? What did we just do with our ruler, when we lined it up vertically?
speaker: teacher

text: Equivalent fractions. That’s what we’re really looking for. Use the equivalent fractions to help you.  If it helps that you need to turn it into a percent to find the equivalent fraction with a percent, that’s fine to do.  Okay, with your partner right now, you’re going to complete your track.
speaker: teacher

text: Can you fine [inaudible] fraction on here that’s labeled that’s equivalent? One that’s already done for you?  Well, you know [inaudible] here, right?
speaker: teacher

text: How did you know to put one-third there?
speaker: teacher

text: These are two-thirds [inaudible].  I’m measuring [inaudible] right there, so I [inaudible] and got this one and then [inaudible].
speaker: student

text: Now, using your ruler vertically, can you tell what fractions are equivalent to one-third?
speaker: teacher

text: What fraction that is labeled is equivalent to one-third?
speaker: teacher

text: Can everybody [inaudible] put your hands on your [heads].  As you’re finishing, some of you are [going] more quickly than others.  Your [sponge] activity.  I have fractions listed, and you’re going to find equivalent fractions for those fractions.  If you’re done, you can do it on a scrap piece of paper.  You can do it on the back of this track.  You could do it in your notebook, if you have your notebook there.
speaker: teacher

text: Can you tell me which tracks down here are equivalent and [inaudible]?

text: Miss [inaudible], do we [inaudible] our papers when we’re done?

text: [Inaudible.] [Inaudible.]  Can you show me other equivalent fractions [inaudible]?  Good job.  What else?  Show me one more. Good job.

text: I’m noticing here that you have one-third here and you have this very large space in-between zero-thirds and one-third [inaudible].  Is there any other [inaudible] large spaces. So do you think you could use another fraction on this track to help you [inaudible] one-third?  Which fraction?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  Excellent.  So where is your ruler?  That’s why I gave you rulers, to help you find exactly where [inaudible]. Here.  So, if two-thirds [inaudible] are equivalent, where should a one-third go?

text: Good job.  Can you find other equivalent fractions on here?

text: Which ones?  Good.  [Inaudible.]  Can you find another one that [inaudible]?
speaker: teacher

text: [Inaudible] that one.  I think most of you are finished doing your [inaudible].  Good.  Thirty more seconds and then we’re going to move on.

text: Okay.  What do you notice when you’re [inaudible]?

text: Can you show me another one that’s on this?  [Inaudible] the halves.  One-half, two-fourths, three-sixths, four-eights, and five-tenths.  [Inaudible] the same and they’re exactly [half right].  That’s what [inaudible].  So now using – you don’t [inaudible] – using your ruler, can you show me other fractions that might [inaudible], that line up?
speaker: teacher

text: Oh.  Interesting.  So is that [inaudible] one-fourth lines up with two-eights?  What does that mean?  [Inaudible.]

text: Because [inaudible].  Where did you get the 10 from?

text: [Inaudible.]  So 6 times – here [inaudible].  You need to [inaudible].  [Inaudible] just do one fraction at a time. All right.  All of you are done with the fraction track. Let’s look back up here.  I want you to tell me some things that you noticed on your fraction track, and I want you tell me a strategy of how you figured out what fractions go where on your track.  Yes?

text: Student M knows that two-thirds is equivalent to four-sixths, so she said that she lined up her ruler at two-thirds, and it lined right up with the dot, four-sixths.  Great job. Did anybody else use that strategy?
